messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Digest Number 1526
messages.msgSnippet: She ordered it from The Pyramid Collection catalog.  It is called the Book of Good Spells or something along that
messages.messageBody:
<<My son would love a book of spells>>

She ordered it from "The Pyramid Collection" catalog. It is called the
"Book of Good Spells" or something along that line. It is gypsy spells and
kind of fun. I have also seen books of spells at Barnes and Noble.

Julie

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Digest Number 1526
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Pam, I m wondering what kind of book store you have in your home. I love this idea. Do you make any money? Leslie ... From: Pam Hartley To:
messages.messageBody:
Hi Pam,
I'm wondering what kind of book store you have in your home. I love this idea. Do you make any money?
Leslie
----- Original Message -----
From: Pam Hartley
To: Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, October 06, 2001 12:33 AM
Subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Digest Number 1526




----------
>From: Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com
>To: Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [Unschooling-dotcom] Digest Number 1526
>Date: Fri, Oct 5, 2001, 8:41 PM
>

> Who are you people ?
> Ya know what , don't answer

Too late. <g> I am Pamela Denise Hartley nee Ortel, living in Tracy,
California with two daughters, 1 husband, 1 dog, 1 cat, 4 rats and an
in-home bookstore. I enjoy long walks, longer baths, reading, sleeping, and
eating chocolate. My favorite color is green. My favorite actor is Michael
Ironside. My favorite restaurant is Tio Pepe's in Manteca (they have two
branches in Stockton, too).

> because I don't much care
> as long as you're not my neighbor .

Bad news. We are all your neighbors.

Welcome to the world, with all its warts.

Pam, Wart-at-large

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Digest Number 1526
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 10/05/2001 10:51:11 PM Central Daylight Time, Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 10/05/2001 10:51:11 PM Central Daylight Time,
Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com writes:

<<
There are more of us in the country than there are fundamentalist Christians
who are afraid of Harry Potter books!

Sandra
who often pussy-foots around Christians out of courtesy, but this was too in
my face for a fine October 5, 2001 >>

Just a public service announcement:

Let us remember that there are ENORMOUS distinctions between
"Fundamentalist Christians" (specifically) and "Christians" (generally). I
would wager to say that we of the "general variety" greatly outnumber those
of the "fundamentalist variety", and thus the latter variety (fundamentalist
Christians) is most DEFINITELY a subset (and not a defining subset, at that
<g>) of the former.

Thank you and I will now return to my regular semi-lurking behavior. :-)



*** Becky***

"Nothing in all the world is more dangerous than sincere ignorance and
conscientious stupidity."

Martin Luther King Jr. (1929 - 1968), Strength to Love, 1963
